explanation:
For determining whether the conditional mapping in OS_mkfs constitutes dead code (i.e. can be removed without changing program behaviour) the analyzer needs the following symbols and why:

- OS_FileSys_Initialize
  - Required to know which return values it can actually produce in the deployed build (and thus whether the if-condition can ever be true). Also to inspect whether it is a thin wrapper to other code that already returns the historical error code.

- OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE
  - The code tests for this specific return value; its numeric value and intended semantics are needed to determine if the comparison can succeed at runtime and whether it is distinct from other error codes.

- OS_ERR_NO_FREE_IDS
  - Same reason as above: the mapping depends on this specific constant; need its definition and whether OS_FileSys_Initialize can return it.

- OS_FS_ERR_DEVICE_NOT_FREE
  - The function rewrites the two historic error codes to this value. Need its numeric value and documented meaning to know whether the rewrite affects observable behaviour (e.g. callers inspect this value).

- OS_initfs
  - The comment in OS_mkfs references historic mkfs()/initfs() behaviour. Inspecting OS_initfs (which also calls OS_FileSys_Initialize per the call graph) shows whether the same compatibility mapping exists elsewhere and whether removing the mapping in OS_mkfs would change global behaviour or break compatibility.

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType
- UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData
- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler
- UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr
  - The static call graph includes these unit-test stub framework functions as callees (test builds may instrument or override OS_FileSys_Initialize/OS_mkfs). They are required to determine whether test-time instrumentation can change/force return values (making the branch reachable or not) and to distinguish behaviour between production and test builds. If stubs can inject returns that make the if-block executable only in tests, that affects whether the code is considered dead in production versus test configurations.

Together these symbols let an analyst decide (a) whether the if-condition can be true in any relevant build/configuration, (b) whether mapping to OS_FS_ERR_DEVICE_NOT_FREE changes observable behaviour for callers (including OS_initfs and any other callers), and (c) whether the mapping exists only for test compatibility or for deployed code — all necessary to assess the MISRA dead-code rule for this function.
